US Market Wrap - 27th September 2019: Trump officials mulling restricting portfolio flows to China
content:
• SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar flat, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Trump mulls capital restrictions on China; Harker says rates are ok for now; mixed personal income and spending; Michigan sentiment contrasts with CB confidence; BOE Saunders dovish; Saudi/Yemen partial truce.
  • NEXT WEEK: MON: Japanese Industrial Production, Chinese Manufacturing and non-Manufacturing PMI, Caixin Manufacturing PMI, German Retail Sales, Import Price Index, Jobs Report, Regional and National CPI, UK GDP (2nd), EZ Unemployment Rate, US Chicago PMI, Dallas Fed Manufacturing PMI, NZ Business Confidence. TUE: Chinese National Day, South Korean CPI, Japanese Tankan, Unemployment Rate, Manufacturing PMI, South Korean Trade, Manufacturing PMI, RBA Policy Announcement, Australian Building Approvals, EZ Manufacturing PMI (F), EZ CPI, Canadian GDP, UK and US (F) Manufacturing PMI, US Construction Spending, ISM Manufacturing. WED: Swiss CPI, UK Construction PMI, ADP Employment Change. THU: Japanese Services PMI, Australian Trade, EZ, UK, US Services and Composite PMI, EZ PPI and Retail Sales, US Challenger Jobs Cuts, US Factory Orders, ISM Non-Manufacturing. FRI: RBI Rate Decision, US NFP, Canadian Trade. Click here for week in focus preview; click here for weekly central bank briefing.

* US/CHINA: Sources said Trump officials were mulling restricting portfolio flows into China, though no timeline has yet been decided. The Bloomberg report also said officials were considering delisting China firms from US stock exchanges. The news injected a considerable risk-off tone, as it would be considered a notable escalation in trade wars. As traders digested the news, the immediate knee jerk reaction pared with traders reasoning that there was no indication such a policy would be imminent, and it remains unclear what sort of mechanism the US could use to enforce such a policy; additionally, it is being framed as a 'consideration'.

* FED: Fed's Harker (non-voter, though will vote in 2020; neutral) said he could be open to a rate cut, but not right now. Harker, who votes on policy next year, said the Fed was close to the balance sheet unwind ending. On incoming data, Harker said the recent consumer data was a little weak (he spoke before today's Michigan release), and Harker thinks that the Fed should be on hold with interest rates. Meanwhile, Fed's Quarles largely stayed away from monetary policy, though did see the US economy as 'solid'.

* US AUGUST PERSONAL INCOME AND SPENDING: Personal income was in line with expectations, at 0.4% M/M, though personal spending was short of the consensus at 0.1% M/M. The data underscores consumer caution in the face of severe trade and financial market turbulence, Oxford Economics said, adding that while the core of the US economy remains strong, spending momentum has decelerated to its slowest pace this year as consumers continues to significantly cut back their outlays on services. Core PCE, meanwhile, rose by 0.1% M/M in August, slightly short of consensus, though the Y/Y rate was unchanged at 1.8%, as was expected. Oxford Economics continues to believe in a medium-term inflation undershoot of the Fed’s 2% inflation goal, and says it believes these data will favor another rate cut in October.

* US DURABLE GOODS: Headline durable goods orders rose +0.2% M/M in august, topping the consensus view; the ex-transport measure wa salso above consensus, though core capital goods orders declined by more than the consensus had expected. The headline was boosted by a rebound in aircraft orders. The core measure was again buoyed by capex orders, which have been outperforming vs the ISM data. However, Pantheon Macroeconomics says that the risk is clearly to the downside for the foreseeable future: "Other capex indicators, notably the NFIB survey, have weakened markedly too. We expect no relief here until the trade war is over, and we are becoming increasingly convinced that won’t happen until after the 2020 election. In the meantime, we expect core orders to decline, with business capex in GDP to follow.

* BOE: BoE's Saunders (Hawk) said prolonged Brexit uncertainty might warrant looser monetary policy if global growth remained disappointing, adding that the adverse effects of high uncertainty are becoming clearer in UK macro data. Saunders believes the economy has slowed markedly since early this year, but had not crashed. However, Brexit uncertainties were perhaps akin to the economy developing a slow puncture such that growth has slowed to a mere crawl, he said. Saunders said that some further monetary tightening – limited and gradual – probably would be needed to return inflation to target on a sustained basis if global growth recovers, and Brexit uncertainty falls significantly, and if the UK avoids a no-deal Brexit, policy could go either way, with Saunders suggesting that it was quite plausible that the next move in Bank Rate would be down rather than up.

* GEOPOLITICAL: Iranian President Rouhani reportedly said that at the UN the US had offered to remove all sanctions on Iran in return for dialogue, a statement which saw a leg lower in oil prices (where the geopolitical risk premium  as participants jumped on the dovish statement which had been at odds to the commentary from both Iran and the US earlier in the week. US President Trump later responded that Iran had wanted the US to lift sanctions, but “of course” he refused. Geopolitical tensions in the gulf seemingly de-escalated earlier in the session, if one uses crude oil benchmarks as a barometer, after the WSJ reported that Saudi Arabia had agreed to a partial ceasefire with Yemen, although talking heads were sceptical of such claims given prior ceasefires have failed to uphold; the Pentagon on Thursday announced it was sending a slew of military resources to Saudi’s aid.

* CRUDE WRAP: Crude prices dropped to levels seen before the recent attacks on Saudi energy facilities as traders priced-out the geopolitical risk premium within black gold. Saudi Arabia has announced a partial ceasefire in Yemen, Iran has finally released the UK-flagged tanker Stena Impero, and there were also some headlines where Iran President Rouhani appeared to suggest that the US had offered to remove sanctions in return for talks (although this was denied, and reporters note the translations were dubious). The question now, Citi says, is whether the market has fallen far enough to make at least some traders willing to buy the dip. The bank argues that on a fundamental basis, it continues to see a H2 2019 supply/demand deficit that was only expanded by the production losses in Saudi Arabia, and it thinks that the market may have a further chance to rally as OPEC production estimates for September begin circulating next week, encouraging traders to review the math. The bank notes that, while Saudi Arabia may be restoring production capacity and ramping up actual supply, the market is still tighter than it was two weeks ago.

* FX WRAP: The offshore yuan weakened to over 7.15 against the USD after news that the US was mulling restricting China capital market access. The EUR fell to two-year lows on Friday, on weak EZ growth outlook this week, though 1.09 held, and the single currency rebounded back above 1.0925. GBP eased to below 1.23 after dovish commentary from the BOE’s (usually hawkish) Saunders. EMFX weaker, tracking yuan, and despite USD retaining an offered. Havens are flat-to-lower, though gold’s fall is notable (sub 1500) on geopolitical developments. Click here for weekly FX wrap.   

* TREASURIES: Although yields are down in the TPLEX, the curve has steepened slightly in wake of reports suggesting Trump officials were considering a policy to restrict portfolio flows to China, and are also mulling delisting Chinese stocks from US exchanges. Fed Overnight Repo operations today saw USD 22.7bln bids submitted (Fed had offered USD 100bln), and the 14-day term operation was under-subscribed, seeing USD 49bln accepted of the USD 60bln offered; while both indicate money market stress has abated, attention will be on Monday’s operations, to observe month/quarter-end effect, and the digestion of this week’s Treasury supply. In later trade, the TPLEX was supported by comments from China diplomat Wang Yi, who struck a defiant tone, suggesting China would not be bullied, contributing to a risk-off feel as we close out the week. T-Notes (Z9) settled 3+ ticks higher at 130-12+.

* S&P 500 -0.5% at 2962, NASDAQ-100 -1.2% at 7682, Dow Jones  -0.3% at 26824; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  -0.4%, Consumer Staples  -0.1%, Energy  0%, Financials  0.3%, Health Care  -0.4%, Industrials  -0.4%, Information Technology  -1.3%, Materials  -0.3%, Telecommunication Services  -0.9%, Utilities  -0.3%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Micron’s (MU) earnings beat on both top and bottom line, however its gross margin fell to 50.2% from a prior 58.42% and forecasted its median EPS for Q1 beneath expectations. MU said it is encouraged by signs of an improving industry demand, however, it was mindful of ongoing macro and trade uncertainties. RBC noted that it did not provide commentary suggesting prices had bottomed out, a statement anticipated in the SOX sector in recent days. The message instead showed that NAND pricing is comfortably improving, however the question remains on its DRAM. MU also noted that equipment spending could fall as low as 30%, deeper than investor consensus for a 15-20% fall. The poor guidance and concerns around DRAM prices hit competitors Lam Research (LRCX) and Applied Materials (AMAT). Chinese ADR’s (BABA, BIDU, JD) were heavily pressured after it was announced that the US is mulling limits on US portfolio flows into China and also the delisting of Chinese companies from US stock exchanges. Alphabet (GOOGL) traded lower today amid a mixed set of headlines, where Oracle (ORCL) announced it has received requests for information on GOOGL over a range of business issues, however, its chief of cloud operations stated the trade war has not affected sales growth and it is seeing enormous global growth. Pfizer (PFE) phase 3 study of “Abrocitinib” achieved its primary endpoint, whilst also announcing its chairman is to retire with the CEO to replace him. Wells Fargo (WFC) an outperformer today on the announcement of a new CEO, Charles Scharf, who left Bank of New York Mellon (BK) (the latter lower on the day). Latam Airlines ARR’s (LTM) traded over 30% higher as Delta Airlines (DAL) took a 20% stake in the name, valued at USD 1.9bln. Marathon Petroleum (MPC) received a letter from investors who are looking to remove its CEO Heminger, however it was later announced the investors who sent the letter held a 1.7% stake, and the remaining investors actually supported the CEO.

subject: Weekly FX Wrap: Dollar eyes yearly highs, Euro slipped to YTD lows and Lira remains in EM limelight
content:
DXY

A stellar week for the Dollar as the index stopped just shy of returning to YTD highs. UBS noted that foreign equities, particularly Japanese, have outperformed US stocks in September, which “implies that hedge rebalancing pressures could favor the US dollar”. On the domestic political front, US House Speaker Pelosi opened an impeachment inquiry in US President Trump over a controversial phone call between himself and his Ukrainian counterpart in which the US President allegedly threatened to withhold military aid to Ukraine unless Zelensky finds dirt on 2020 Presidential candidate Biden. The transcript of the call seems to be less grave than people feared given that Trump only asked for an inquiry related to Biden, but it is unclear if the US President withheld funds for that reason. The House is set to go on recess today for two weeks, thus participants will still be eyeing developments in Capitol Hill late doors. Data this week did little to impact the Buck. DXY is set to end the European week closer to the top of this week’s range (98.29-99.31) ahead of the YTD high 99.37. Looking ahead, next week’s notable releases include ISM PMIs, and the US Labour Market Report alongside a slew of Fed speakers.

EUR, GBP

The Single Currency and the Pound have suffered heavy losses this week with the former initially hit by dismal Flash PMIs which highlighted that Germany may not see any growth before the end of the year, whilst Q3 EZ GDP growth is poised to rise just 0.1%. Further, the Ifo institute added that the outlook for the German economy has deteriorated, the domestic economy is likely to shrink in Q3 and stagnate in the quarter after. In terms of ECB speak, Chief Economist Lane stated that the ECB has further room to cut rates and the that the 12th policy announcement was not a dramatic policy move but rather a recalibration. The above, coupled with Dollar strength saw EUR/USD back below the 1.1000 level (weekly high 1.1026) and to fresh YTD lows of 1.0906 ahead of bids at 1.0880-90 and a Fib at 1.0864. Meanwhile, Sterling was swayed by Brexit and domestic news-flow after PM Johnson’s decision to prorogue parliament was deemed unlawful. This saw Cable climb to its weekly high of 1.2500, although upon the return of parliament (and profit taking), the pair saw its biggest weekly decline with the path to Brexit still unclear. Downside in GBP/USD exacerbated amid a firmer Dollar and comments from BoE-hawk Saunders as he stated that "prolonged high Brexit uncertainty" could warrant looser monetary policy if global growth remains disappointing whilst an aversion of a no-deal Brexit still means that rates could go either way. GBP/USD fell from further and breached 1.2300 to the downside to a weekly low of 1.2272 ahead of its 50 DMA at 1.2262.

AUD, NZD

Poised to end the week mixed with the Kiwi on the front-foot, albeit off its weekly high and the Aussie modestly softer. NZD was underpinned by the RBNZ standing pat on its OCR at 1% and maintaining a neutral bias despite some calls for an easing bias to be reintroduced. Furthermore, Governor Orr struck an optimistic tone on the domestic economy and noted that current conditions do not warrant unconventional policy tools. NZD/USD poised to end the EU week closer to the middle of this week’s 0.6258-0.6350 range having opened at 0.6298. Meanwhile, AUD was initially buoyed by optimistic trade tones from China earlier in the week, although Governor Lowe gave the most notable boost as he noted (and reiterated) the domestic fundamental factors underpinning the longer-term outlook remain strong and the economy has reached a “gentle turning point”. Strength in the Aussie then dissipated amid a firmer Buck, AUD/USD looks to end the European week flat above 0.6750 having visited a low of 0.6740 and a high of 0.6806. Next week sees the RBA’s monetary policy decision in which the majority of analysts surveyed expect the CB to further lower rates by 25bps, taking its Cash Rate to 0.75%; however, just under half of those surveyed see the Bank standing pat, whilst money markets price a 78% change of a 25bps reduction.

JPY, CHF

Both on track for modestly softer weekly closes, ultimately amid hopes of progress in the US/China saga with most notable move following jawboning by US President Trump who stated that a trade deal may “happen sooner than you think”, which comes ahead of principle-level talks in Washington next month. Further, a strengthening Dollar added pressure to the safe havens. USD/JPY twice tested but failed to convincingly breach its 50 DMA (around the 107.05 level) before overcoming its 100 DMA at 107.82 to print a weekly high at 108.16, whilst USD/CHF posted a current weekly range between its 200 and 50 DMAs (0.9846 and 0.9948).

EM

The week saw a mixed performance across the EM space, but the Lira stands out as the clear outperformer with initial strength due to reports that the US is poised to make a new offer to Turkey in regards to the F-35 fighter jets and the Patriot missile system, although Turkey (at the back end of the week) noted that discussions were ongoing regarding a Russian SU-35 fighter jets deal (the alternative to the US F-35s) but nothing is set in stone. Further, the CBRT Governor Usyual reiterated that a cautious monetary stance will be maintained whilst acknowledging the normalisation in inflation and an economic recovering in H2. USD/TRY poised to end the week in the red and back below the 5.70 level having fallen below its 100 DMA tested bids at the weekly low of 5.65 (vs. high 5.74).

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 27th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) Q4 19 (USD): adj. EPS 0.56 (exp. 0.46), Revenue 4.87bln (exp. 4.53bln). Adj. Gross Margin 50.2% (Prev. 58.42%).
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) (Financials/Diversified Banks) names Charles Scharf as new CEO and President; Scharf was chairman and CEO of The Bank of New York Mellon Corp. (BK) (Financials/Asset Management & Custody Banks), who has stepped down subsequentially.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is reportedly in late stage talks with the striking union, UAW.

Semiconductors (SOX) - Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) Q4 19 (USD): adj. EPS 0.56 (exp. 0.46), Revenue 4.87bln (exp. 4.53bln). Adj. Gross Margin 50.2% (Prev. 58.42%). Co says it is encouraged by signs of improving industry demand, mindful of continued near-term macro and trade uncertainties. Q1 Revenue view 5bln +/- 200mln (exp. 4.7bln); Q1 EPS view 0.39-0.53 (exp. 0.52), Co says it is well positioned to address robust industry demand. RBC notes that the co. did not provide commentary suggesting we’re “past the bottom”, and that the message instead portrayed that NAND pricing is comfortably improving, however, the question remains around DRAM prices. Equipment spending could be down as much as 30%, a larger decline than what investors were expecting of around down 15-20%. Micron forecast further ongoing uncertainty surrounding US/China trade talks. Baird has noted that the DRAM trough still has a long way to go, and its analysts expect price declines to accelerate late October and expect a trough in the May quarter.

Also of note for Semiconductors, TSMC’s (TSM) supply of 16nm, 12nm, 10nm chips are reportedly tight. (DigiTimes)

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals)  is planning to release feature length films to theatres before releasing them on its streaming TV service. (WSJ)
  • Pfizer Inc. (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) says its second Phase 3 study of “Abrocitinib” achieved its primary endpoint for evaluation the efficacy and safety of the drug in patients aged 12 or older, with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis. Elsewhere, its Chairman of the board is to retire, with CEO Bourala to replace him.
  • Visa Inc. (V) (Information Technology/IT Services) announced it is planning to deposit USD 300mln into a litigation escrow account.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc Class C (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) Cloud chief said the trade disputes has not affected sales growth and that it is seeing enormous growth around the world. (CNBC)
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) Libra Association Managing Director said the crypto currency is not intended to replace existing currencies. Adding they are in discussions with the EU after Germany and France announced their opposition to the currency and that if the launch is pushed back by one or two quarters from the initial date June 2020, it is not an issue for the association. Also of note for FB, a Senior Russian Lawmaker will send questions to CEO Zuckerberg about company complying with Russian laws.
  • Oracle Corp. (ORCL) (Information Technology/Application Software) says it has received requests for information about Alphabet Inc Class C (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) over a range of business issues, according to CNBC.

S&P 500

  • AbbVie Inc. (ABBV) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) received FDA approval of its Mavyret to shorten treatment for Hepatitis C.
  • Altria Group Inc (MO) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco) Juul labs asked to have the lawsuits against e-cigarettes sent to its hometown San Francisco.
  • AT&T Inc. (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) forecasts its 2019 FCF to be approximately USD 28bln with a free cash flow dividend pay-out ratio of 50.6%.
  • Cummins Inc. (CMI) (Industrials/Industrial Machinery) is to partner with Hyundai Motor to evaluate opportunities to develop and commercialise electric and fuel cell power trains.
  • Delta Air Lines Inc. (DAL) (Industrials/Airlines) has taken a 20% stake in Latam Airlines (LTM) at a value of USD 1.9bln. (CNBC)
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) recommended holders reject the mini-tender offer by Novos First to purchase 600,000 shares at USD 7.65/shr.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is reportedly in late stage talks with the striking union, UAW. (WSJ)
  • Jefferies Financial Group (JEF) (Financials/Multi-Sector Holdings) Q3 19 (USD): EPS USD 0.16 (Exp. 0.13), revenue 856.8mln (Exp. 993.2mln)
  • Marathon Petroleum (MPC) (Energy/Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing) investors are looking to remove its CEO Gary Heminger, citing a copy of letter sent to the company. MPC later announced the shareholders 1.7% of stock and that they support CEO Heminger. (WSJ)
  • Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) is to be replaced by Las Vegas Sands (LVS) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) in the S&P 500 on the 3rd October.
  • PPG Industries (PPG) (Materials/Specialty Chemicals) reports an investigation by SEC and DOJ resulted in no financial fine to the company.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 27th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Major European indices are firmer following on from a choppy Asia-Pac session
  • FTSE 100 outperforms as Sterling slips and Gilts gain on dovish BoE Saunders
  • Saudi Arabia have reportedly agreed to a partial ceasefire in Yemen, according to the WSJ
  • US-China principal-level trade talks will take place on October 10-11th in Washington DC
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Personal Income, Core PCE, PCE Price Index, Durable Goods, University of Michigan (F), Baker Hughes Rig Count, ECB’s Lane, Weidmann, Fed’s Quarles and Harker

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly subdued following the weak lead from Wall St where all major indices finished negative on what was a choppy session due to trade uncertainty and as political concerns regarding the whistleblower complaint lingered. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) were mixed in which Australia bucked the overall downbeat trend in the region ahead of next week’s anticipated RBA rate cut although metal names and gold miners lagged as the precious metal eyed the USD 1500/oz level to the downside, while the Japanese benchmark was led lower by losses in Kansai Electric after reports of illicit payoffs and with notable declines in SoftBank due to the ongoing WeWork woes. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) trades lacklustre as participants mulled over the latest trade rhetoric in which an official stated the US is unlikely to extend temporary waivers to supply Huawei although reports later noted no decision has been made and US-China talks are to resume on October 10th-11th, while the latest data provided no comfort as Chinese Industrial Profits contracted by 2%. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with mild support seen amid underperformance of stocks in Tokyo but with the gains in bonds capped by predominantly weaker results at the 2yr JGB auction. 

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 10bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0731 vs. Exp. 7.0883 (Prev. 7.0729)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Aug) Y/Y -2.0% (Prev. 2.6%). (Newswires)

US-China principal-level trade talks will take place on October 10-11th in Washington DC, according to CNBC citing sources. (CNBC)

US

 

Fed's Barkin (non-voter, hawkish) said the recent rate cuts does not mean the Fed is in a prolonged easing period and that the economy is giving mixed signals due to the strong labour market but low inflation. Barkin added that not easing could undermine the credibility of the 2% inflation target or leave policy makers behind the curve if growth slows further, but over easing could overstimulate inflation, distort labour markets or fuel an asset price bubble, while he suggested that it is too early in the cycle to determine if another rate cut is needed. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

EU has warned that it may be forced to start withdrawing from the nuclear deal in November if Iran goes ahead its threats to takes new steps away from the deal. (Guardian)

, while other reports suggested US officials may be in North Korea to lay the groundwork for talks which could take place in the next few weeks. (Newswires/Korea Times)

North Korea said lack of progress casts doubts on prospects for future summit with US and that US failure to implement agreements make breakthrough doubtful but added that it sees US President Trump as different and places hope on his wisdom and bold decision. (KCNA)

Turkish President Erdogan said issues of F-35 jets with US is not yet completely resolved and proposed to US President Trump to buy Patriot defence system if US can match Russia S-400 deal. (Newswires)

UK/EU

BoE's Saunders (Hawk) says "prolonged high Brexit uncertainty" could warrant looser monetary policy if global growth remains disappointing. If the UK avoids a no-deal Brexit, monetary policy also could go either way and I think it is quite plausible that the next move in Bank Rate would be down rather than up. And the adverse effects of high uncertainty are becoming cleare in UK data. (Newswires/BoE)

UK PM Johnson faces a revolt in which 3 Cabinet ministers plan to confront him after the Tory annual conference and demand he drops the strategy of trying to bluff EU with the threat of a no-deal, as well as insist he accept a last-minute deal. (The Sun)

EU diplomatic sources are adamant there will be no negotiations on the Brexit deal at the Oct 17 EU summit, according to Telegraph's James Crisp. (Twitter)

EU's Juncker said we are doing all we can to achieve a deal and that it will be Britain's fault if we don't. (Newswires)

If no effective agreement on digital tax is reached internally by end-2020, the EU should act alone, says EU Economy and Tax Commissioner Gentiloni. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

 

Major European indices are firmer this morning, with the FTSE 100 (+1.2%) leading the way after dovish comments from BoE Hawk Saunders caused Sterling to slip. Sectors are all in the green bar IT, which is hampered by broad-based downside in European chip names following Micron’s earnings last night where their EPS guidance missed exp. and they noted near term macro and trade uncertainties. Elsewhere, Commerzbank (+1.5%) are subdued as the Co. state they no-longer anticipate an increase in underlying revenue for 2019; although, they have launched a public acquisition offer for Comdirect Bank at EUR 11.44/shr. Sticking with Germany but moving into the DAX (+0.9%) where BASF (+3.0%) have confirmed their mid-term outlook and the additional EUR 2bln in savings by 2021; additionally, the CEO anticipates an Oil and Gas IPO in H2 2020. Separately, Rheinmetall (-2.3%) are weaker after reporting that production in the US, Mexico and Brazil has been severely impacted by a malware attack. Today’s notable in-hours story is from AMS (-7.5%) who have submitted their final offer for Osram Licht (+3.3%) in which they have increased their offer by EUR 2.50/shr for the Co.

 

Beijing have reportedly rejected reports that Chinese hackers were suspected of being behind a series of cyber attacks on Airbus (AIR FP)., AFP News

 

Apple (AAPL) plans to bring feature length films to theaters, according to WSJ. (WSJ)

 

FX

 

GBP, EUR - The Pound is the marked G10 laggard after BOE MPC-hawk Saunders surprisingly took a more dovish stance as he stated that looser monetary policy could be warranted amid “prolonged high Brexit uncertainty” coupled with disappointing global growth and as the adverse effects of  high uncertainty is becoming clearer in domestic macro data. Saunders also noted that in the even the UK avoids a no-deal, rates could go either way, i.e. a rate cut is still on the table in the event a no-deal Brexit is averted. Cable gave up the 1.2300 handle (from around 1.2330) to an intraday low of 1.2270 ahead of its 50 DMA at 1.2262. Meanwhile the EUR is flat on the day after the earlier softness in the single currency was countered by an even softer Sterling post-Saunders. Meanwhile, the EUR initially felt pressure amid an interview by ECB-dove Lane who stated the ECB has further room to ease and that the stimulus package announced was a relatively smaller one in his opinion. EUR/USD resides around 1.0925 having visited a low of 1.0905 ahead of reported bids at the psychological 1.0900 level, 1.0880-90 and a Fib at 1.0864. EUR/GBP remains firm just under 0.8900 having hit an intraday high of 0.8896.

 

DXY - Firmer on the day with the index eyeing YTD highs of 99.37 having already reached an intraday peak at 99.31. The Dollar gains seen recently are in the absence of clear catalysts, although market participants point to month and quarter-end as a potential factor. UBS notes that foreign equities, particularly Japanese, have outperformed US stocks in September, which “implies that hedge rebalancing pressures could favor the US dollar”. Meanwhile, the weakening Euro amid further deterioration in the EZ may also be underpinning the Greenback. DXY currently resides just below 99.25 ahead of the YTD peak. USD/JPY meanwhile has breached 108.00 to the upside amid the strength in the Buck (ahead of the September high at 108.48 and the psychological 108.50). Looking ahead, the State-side docket sees the release of the Core PCE metrics alongside Durable Goods with Fed’s Quarles (voter) and Harker (non-voter) due to speak later.

 

AUD, NZD - The Aussie bucks the trends and remains firm ahead of next week’s RBA rate decision. Money markets are currently pricing in around a 78% chance of a 25bps cut, although support for the currency could be derived from Morgan Stanley’s call for the RBA to stand pat until further economic data is available, whilst firmer copper prices also underpin the currency. AUD/USD is back above the 0.6750 level whilst AUD/NZD tested 1.0750 to the upside (vs. low of 1.0720), in turn pressuring NZD/USD back below 0.6300.

 

SEK - The Scandi Crown remains weaker against the Euro amid disappointing retail sales which saw the MM and YY figures miss forecasts. EUR/SEK breached its 50 DMA at 10.6898 and now eyes 10.6900 to the upside having printed an intraday low at 10.6520.

 

FIXED

Bunds are starting the session, and finishing the week, little changed thus far; as news flow for the Continent has been sparse, German debt hovering around the 174.30 mark in the middle of a sub-40 tick range. Gilts, in contrast, have had an eventful morning following the aforementioned comments from BoE Hawk Saunders who exhibited a decidedly dovish tone; following this, Gilts rose from session lows of circa 133.80 to print a session high of 134.48. On the upside there is resistance in the form of recent highs at 134.79; as a reminder Tory Party conference begins this weekend, which will likely see updates on both the domestic and Brexit situation. The remainder of the session is devoid of notable highlights from a European perspective, though comments from ECB’s Lane this afternoon will be of note, particularly given yesterday’s press pieces which were upbeat, though there are some reporting discrepancies over comments regarding further rate cuts. Stateside, a busier end to the week with a number of data prints and speakers ahead. Currently, USTs are slightly softer though similarly to their European counterpart are towards the centre of the days range at 130.04; while the curve is marginally bear steepening at present, though not by a significant magnitude.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures fell deeper into negative territory as the geopolitical risk premium unwound further amid reports that Saudi Arabia has agreed to establish a partial ceasefire in Yemen which follows reports of US aiding Saudi Arabia bolster its defences. The WSJ article took WTI below the 56.00/bbl mark and under the cluster of DMAs including its 50 DMA (56.02/bbl), 100 DMA (56.63/bbl) and 200 DMA (56.66/bbl), whilst Brent lost the USD 62.00 handle. Elsewhere, gold prices are on the backfoot amid a firmer Greenback as the yellow metal dips below the 1500/oz mark to a current low of 1491/oz. Meanwhile copper prices are firmer with upside attributed to signs of progress in US/China trade talks with a date now set for principal level talks, according to sources. Copper is back above USD 2.58/lb ahead with the next level to the upside the psychological 2.60/lb mark.

Saudi Arabia agrees to a partial ceasefire in Yemen, according to the WSJ

IEA Chief Birol says we may have to cut oil demand growth expectations for 2019 and 2020 if the global economy continues to weaken. (Newswires)

subject: Saudi Arabia agrees to a partial ceasefire in Yemen, according to the WSJ
content: • Link to article here
reaction_details: • Brent (X9) falls from 62.40 to 61.58 in recent trade, as did WTI (X9) from 56.35 to 55.58
analysis_details:
• The Iranians have been known to operate via the Yemeni Houthi rebel group, who have recently claimed being the culprit on the Saudi Aramco oil facilities (although evidence suggests they couldn't have been the sole culprit based on their military capabilities)
  • On Wednesday it was reported the Pentagon is to deploy, one patriot battery, four sentinel radars and 200 support personnel to Saudi Arabia and the US is looking for contribution from other countries, too; putting additional material on further readiness for potential deployment which includes more patriots and THAAD missile defence systems.

Stateside, a busier end to the week with a number of data prints and speakers ahead. Currently, USTs are slightly softer though similarly to their European counterpart are towards the centre of the days range at 130.04; while the curve is marginally bear steepening at present, though not by a significant magnitude.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent future remain in the red thus far as the geopolitical risk premium seen following reports of US aiding Saudi Arabia bolster its defences somewhat waned late doors as the British-flagged oil tanker, Stena Impero, leaves Iran after being seized for almost two months. News-flow for the complex has been light in early European hours and prices were little swayed by IEA’s Chief Birol who noted that a cut to demand growth forecast may be warranted if global economy continues to weaken. WTI currently resides above the 56.00/bbl mark and in-between a cluster of DMAs including its 50 DMA (56.02/bbl), 100 DMA (56.63/bbl) and 200 DMA (56.66/bbl). Brent remains flat around USD 62.50. Elsewhere, gold prices are on the backfoot amid a firmer Greenback as the yellow metal dips below the 1500/oz mark to a current low of 1496/oz ahead of its 50 DMA at around 1493/oz. Meanwhile copper prices are firmer with upside attributed to signs of progress in US/China trade talks with a date now set for principal level talks, according to sources. Copper is back above USD 2.58/lb ahead with the next level to the upside the psychological 2.60/lb mark.

subject: FX Morning Colour: Sterling hit as hawk leans dovish, Dollar sets sights on YTD highs
content:
GBP, EUR

The Pound is the marked G10 laggard after BOE MPC-hawk Saunders surprisingly took a more dovish stance as he stated that looser monetary policy could be warranted amid “prolonged high Brexit uncertainty” coupled with disappointing global growth and as the adverse effects of  high uncertainty is becoming clearer in domestic macro data. Saunders also noted that in the even the UK avoids a no-deal, rates could go either way, i.e. a rate cut is still on the table in the event a no-deal Brexit is averted. Cable gave up the 1.2300 handle (from around 1.2330) to an intraday low of 1.2270 ahead of its 50 DMA at 1.2262. Meanwhile the EUR is flat on the day after the earlier softness in the single currency was countered by an even softer Sterling post-Saunders. Meanwhile, the EUR initially felt pressure amid an interview by ECB-dove Lane who stated the ECB has further room to ease and that the stimulus package announced was a relatively smaller one in his opinion. EUR/USD resides around 1.0925 having visited a low of 1.0905 ahead of reported bids at the psychological 1.0900 level, 1.0880-90 and a Fib at 1.0864. EUR/GBP remains firm just under 0.8900 having hit an intraday high of 0.8896.

DXY

Firmer on the day with the index eyeing YTD highs of 99.37 having already reached an intraday peak at 99.31. The Dollar gains seen recently are in the absence of clear catalysts, although market participants point to month and quarter-end as a potential factor. UBS notes that foreign equities, particularly Japanese, have outperformed US stocks in September, which “implies that hedge rebalancing pressures could favor the US dollar”. Meanwhile, the weakening Euro amid further deterioration in the EZ may also be underpinning the Greenback. DXY currently resides just below 99.25 ahead of the YTD peak. Looking ahead, the State-side docket sees the release of the Core PCE metrics alongside Durable Goods with Fed’s Quarles (voter) and Harker (non-voter) due to speak later.

AUD, NZD

The Aussie bucks the trends and remains firm ahead of next week’s RBA rate decision. Money markets are currently pricing in around a 78% chance of a 25bps cut, although support for the currency could be derived from Morgan Stanley’s call for the RBA to stand pat until further economic data is available, whilst firmer copper prices also underpin the currency. AUD/USD is back above the 0.6750 level whilst AUD/NZD tested 1.0750 to the upside (vs. low of 1.0720), in turn pressuring NZD/USD back below 0.6300.

SEK

The Scandi Crown remains weaker against the Euro amid disappointing retail sales which saw the MM and YY figures miss forecasts. EUR/SEK breached its 50 DMA at 10.6898 and now eyes 10.6900 to the upside having printed an intraday low at 10.6520.

subject: European equity movers this morning: Eutelsat (ETL FP) +1.8%; Vivendi (VIV FP) +1.4%; Siltronic (WAF GY) -3.0%; Infineon (IFX GY) -3.0%; Rhieinmetall (RHM GY) -2.8%; Commerzbank (CBK GY) -2.1%; ASM (ASM NA) -1.5%
BoE's Saunders (Hawk) says "prolonged high Brexit uncertainty" could warrant looser monetary policy if global growth remains disappointing
content:
• These adverse effects of high uncertainty are becoming clearer in UK macro data.
  • The economy has slowed markedly since early this year
  • The economy has not crashed. But the effect of Brexit uncertainties is perhaps akin to the economy developing a slow puncture such that growth has slowed to a mere crawl.
  • Some further monetary tightening – limited and gradual – probably would be needed to return inflation to target on a sustained basis if global growth recovers and Brexit uncertainty falls significantly
  • If the UK avoids a no-deal Brexit, monetary policy also could go either way and I think it is quite plausible that the next move in Bank Rate would be down rather than up
  • Full speech here
reaction_details: • In an immediate reaction to these dovishly perceived comments from one of the more hawkish members of the MPC, GBP/USD fell from 1.2330 to 1.2290, whilst Dec'19 Gilts rose from 133.80 to 134.48
analysis_details: • Note, the focus on lingering Brexit uncertainty was a focus of the most recent BoE minutes from the September meeting.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

27th September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly subdued following the weak lead from Wall St where all major indices finished negative on what was a choppy session due to trade uncertainty and as political concerns regarding the whistleblower complaint lingered. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.4%) were mixed in which Australia bucked the overall downbeat trend in the region ahead of next week’s anticipated RBA rate cut although metal names and gold miners lagged as the precious metal eyed the USD 1500/oz level to the downside, while the Japanese benchmark was led lower by losses in Kansai Electric after reports of illicit payoffs and with notable declines in SoftBank due to the ongoing WeWork woes. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) trades lacklustre as participants mulled over the latest trade rhetoric in which an official stated the US is unlikely to extend temporary waivers to supply Huawei although reports later noted no decision has been made and US-China talks are to resume on October 10th-11th, while the latest data provided no comfort as Chinese Industrial Profits contracted by 2%.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 27th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were mostly subdued following the weak lead from Wall St, Australia outperformed
  • Chinese Foreign Minister said China is willing to buy more US products needed by the Chinese market, ahead of principal-level talks on October 10-11th in Washington
  • Pentagon is to send 200 troops, a missile system and radar equipment to Saudi Arabia following the attack on its oil facilities
  • In FX markets, the DXY was firmer, EUR/USD edged further below 1.1000; USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were indecisive
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Economic Sentiment, US Personal Income, Core PCE, PCE Price Index, Durable Goods, University of Michigan (F), Baker Hughes Rig Count, BoE’s Saunders, ECB’s de Guindos, Lane, Weidmann, Riksbank’s Floden, Fed’s Quarles and Harker

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly subdued following the weak lead from Wall St where all major indices finished negative on what was a choppy session due to trade uncertainty and as political concerns regarding the whistleblower complaint lingered. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.4%) were mixed in which Australia bucked the overall downbeat trend in the region ahead of next week’s anticipated RBA rate cut although metal names and gold miners lagged as the precious metal eyed the USD 1500/oz level to the downside, while the Japanese benchmark was led lower by losses in Kansai Electric after reports of illicit payoffs and with notable declines in SoftBank due to the ongoing WeWork woes. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) trades lacklustre as participants mulled over the latest trade rhetoric in which an official stated the US is unlikely to extend temporary waivers to supply Huawei although reports later noted no decision has been made and US-China talks are to resume on October 10th-11th, while the latest data provided no comfort as Chinese Industrial Profits contracted by 2%. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with mild support seen amid underperformance of stocks in Tokyo but with the gains in bonds capped by predominantly weaker results at the 2yr JGB auction. 

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 10bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0731 vs. Exp. 7.0883 (Prev. 7.0729)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Aug) Y/Y -2.0% (Prev. 2.6%). (Newswires)

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said China is willing to buy more US products needed by the Chinese market as the US has shown goodwill by waiving tariffs on Chinese products. Furthermore, he hopes both sides can take more "enthusiastic" measures and reduce both negative language as well as actions in the trade dispute, while he added that if everyone does this the talks will yield results. (Newswires)

US-China principal-level trade talks will take place on October 10-11th in Washington DC, according to CNBC citing sources. (CNBC)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson faces a revolt in which 3 Cabinet ministers plan to confront him after the Tory annual conference and demand he drops the strategy of trying to bluff EU with the threat of a no-deal, as well as insist he accept a last-minute deal. (The Sun)

EU's Juncker said we are doing all we can to achieve a deal and that it will be Britain's fault if we don't. (Newswires)

ECB's Lane said we are experiencing a temporary weakness in the economy but added there is no recession and the risk of deflation is small. (Handelsblatt)

UK GfK Consumer Confidence (Sep) -12.0 vs. Exp. -14.0 (Prev. -14.0). (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was firmer after having made its way back above the 99.00 level to approach its best levels in 2 years, while its major counterparts were subdued in which EUR/USD edged further away from the 1.1000 handle and with GBP/USD lacklustre amid Brexit uncertainty with UK PM Johnson insisting that Brexit will happen on October 31st and that there is good chance of getting a deal, although many disagree with this as some EU sources described the chances of the UK and EU reaching a deal as nil. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were indecisive amid a similar risk tone in the region, and antipodeans also lacked conviction due to their high-beta statuses with only minimal gains seen following a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting, while there were also comments from Morgan Stanley on the RBA in which it suggested next week’s decision could be a close call and that the RBA may be waiting to see more economic data.

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly subdued amid the lacklustre risk tone which weighed on oil prices in which WTI crude futures faded some of the geopolitical risk premium seen in late US trade on the back of reports the US was sending missiles and sentinel radars to bolster the Saudi defence forces. Elsewhere, gold remained stuck near the psychological USD 1500/oz level amid a firmer greenback, while the attempt to nurse losses in copper was limited by the lack of risk appetite. 

 

GEOPOLITICS

Pentagon is to deploy one patriot battery, four sentinel radars and 200 support personnel to Saudi Arabia and the US is looking for contribution from other countries also. (Newswires)

EU has warned that it may be forced to start withdrawing from the nuclear deal in November if Iran goes ahead its threats to takes new steps away from the deal. (Guardian)

Iran President Rouhani reiterated the regional crisis can only be resolved through diplomacy, while he reiterated Iran was not involved in the attack and that Tehran does not need to provide evidence. Furthermore, Rouhani said some talks did take place with the US regarding a prisoner swap in which Iran released a prisoner but the US did not reciprocate. In related news, UK tanker Steno Impero which was detained by Iran has left Iran’s Bandar Abbas Port. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US has concluded that Syria’s Assad government used chlorine as a chemical weapon on May 19th and the US has sanctioned two Russian entities for providing fuel to Syria. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US was not able to arrange working level meeting with North Korea in September but the US is ready to meet and believes it is important to do so, while other reports suggested US officials may be in North Korea to lay the groundwork for talks which could take place in the next few weeks. (Newswires/Korea Times)

North Korea said lack of progress casts doubts on prospects for future summit with US and that US failure to implement agreements make breakthrough doubtful but added that it sees US President Trump as different and places hope on his wisdom and bold decision. (KCNA)

Turkish President Erdogan said issues of F-35 jets with US is not yet completely resolved and proposed to US President Trump to buy Patriot defense system if US can match Russia S-400 deal. (Newswires)

US

After Wednesday's bear-steepening on trade optimism, the curve bull-flattened overnight, with desks suggesting the 'impeachment' story remaining influential and that Trump’s off-the-cuff remark on a China trade deal seems to be have been just that, lacking much rationale for the optimism. The US sold USD 32bln in 7-year notes, stopping through the WI by 0.5bps, a notable rebound from the prior 2bps tail; it was a decent auction, printing an above average B/C ratio of 2.49x, with dealers taking below average and indirects taking a chunky 65.2%. US T-note futures (Z9) settled 10+ higher at 130-09.

NY Fed maintained its overnight repo operation at USD 100bln and 14-day term operation at USD 60bln for operations on the 27th September. (Newswires)

Fed's Clarida (voter, neutral) said rising wages were not putting upward pressure on inflation which was running close to the Fed's target and that inflation expectations were consistent with price stability, while he added that the neutral rate appears to have fallen and that the natural rate of unemployment could be 4% or below. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (non-voter, hawkish) said the recent rate cuts does not mean the Fed is in a prolonged easing period and that the economy is giving mixed signals due to the strong labour market but low inflation. Barkin added that not easing could undermine the credibility of the 2% inflation target or leave policy makers behind the curve if growth slows further, but over easing could overstimulate inflation, distort labour markets or fuel an asset price bubble, while he suggested that it is too early in the cycle to determine if another rate cut is needed. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, dove) said he advocated for a steeper rate cut at the September meeting, while he stated there are some signs US businesses are slowing hiring but also noted they are seeing wages slowly start to pick up. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mixed amid trade uncertainty and concerns related to the US whistleblower complaint
content:
Asia equity markets trade indecisive following the weak lead from Wall St where all major indices finished negative on what was a choppy session due to trade uncertainty and as political concerns regarding the whistleblower complaint lingered. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.2%) are mixed as Australia bucks the downbeat trend in the region ahead of next week’s anticipated RBA rate cut although metal names and gold miners lag with the precious metal eyeing the USD 1500/oz level to the downside, while the Japanese benchmark is led lower by losses in Kansai Electric after reports of illicit payoffs and with notable declines in SoftBank due to the ongoing WeWork woes, which it is the largest outside investor in. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) also diverged as participants mull over the latest trade rhetoric in which an official stated the US is unlikely to extend temporary waivers to supply Huawei although reports also noted no decision has been made and that US-China trade talks are to resume on October 10th-11th, while the latest data provided no comfort as Chinese Industrial Profits contracted by 2%.

In FX markets, the DXY is firmer after having made its way back above the 99.00 level to approach its best levels in 2 years, while its major counterparts are subdued after EUR/USD edged further away from the 1.1000 handle and with GBP/USD lacklustre amid Brexit uncertainty with UK PM Johnson insisting that Brexit will happen on October 31st and that there is good chance of getting a deal, although many disagree with this as some EU sources described the chances of the UK and EU reaching a deal as nil. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are indecisive amid a similar risk tone in the region, and there is also a lack of conviction across antipodeans due to their high-beta statuses with only minimal gains seen following a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting, while there were also comments from Morgan Stanley on the RBA in which it suggested next week’s decision could be a close call and that the RBA may be waiting to see more economic data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher with mild support seen amid underperformance of stocks in Tokyo but with the gains in bonds capped as participants await the results of a 2yr JGB auction.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: US is unlikely to extend temporary waivers to supply Huawei according to an official
content:
Budweiser APAC (1876 HK) - Co. partially exercised offer size adjustment option for IPO to raise total offering to 1.45bln shares to cover market demand. (Newswires)

COSCO Shipping Energy Transportation (1138 HK) - Co. will continue its A-Share suspension today as it is still reviewing a major matter. (Newswires)

Goldin Financial Holdings (530 HK) - Co. will pay HKD 4.6bln to acquire Solar Time Developments in connected transaction. (Newswires)

Trade

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said China is willing to buy more US products needed by the Chinese market as the US has shown goodwill by waiving tariffs on Chinese products. Furthermore, he hopes both sides can take more "enthusiastic" measures and reduce both negative language as well as actions in the trade dispute, while he added that if everyone does this the talks will yield results. (Newswires)

Chinese Commerce Ministry said the US and China are closely communicating as well as preparing for making trade talk progress in October although they are still discussing details with the US side, while there were later reports the trade talks are to resume on October 10th-11th in Washington DC. (Newswires/CNBC)

US is unlikely to extend temporary waivers to supply Huawei according to an official, although there were also reports the US said no decision has yet been made on Huawei. (Fox)
